etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or from medieval Latin dislocatio(n-), from the verb dislocare (see dislocate), based on Latin locare ‘to place’

definitions: disturbance from a proper, original, or usual place or state

examples.text: he fell prey to loneliness and a wrenching sense of dislocation
the social dislocations caused by government policies

shortDefinitions: disturbance from proper, original, or usual place or state

definitions: injury or disability caused when the normal position of a joint or other part of the body is disturbed
shortDefinitions: injury or disability caused when normal position of joint or other part of body is disturbed

definitions: a displacement of part of a crystal lattice structure

examples.text: dislocations are present due to the accidents of imperfect growth

shortDefinitions: displacement of part of crystal lattice structure
